qas.question: What type of trains became more energy-efficient in the former Soviet Union?
What year could be marked as year when electric railways more efficient than diesel ones?
How much fuel did electric train used less than diesel in the middle of 1970 in USSR?
What could be a factor of lower energy consumption for electric trains?

answers.text: better operating conditions on electrified lines

qas.question: How much more expensive was diesel compare to electricity per unit?

answers.text: 1.5 times more (per unit of heat energy content

qas.question: In the US, electric traction became more energy-efficient than what?
When was diesel traction three times as efficient as electric traction?
In what decade did electrics use about 35% less fuel per ton-km.

plausible_answers.text: that of the fuel used in electric power plants

qas.question: The cost of diesel was 2.5 times more than what?
Due to the inefficient generation of electricity in the US, diesel traction was twice as energy efficient in what year?

context: In the former Soviet Union, <a0_0>electric<a0_0/> traction eventually became somewhat more energy-efficient than <b5_0>diesel<b5_0/>. Partly due to inefficient generation of electricity in the USSR (only 20.8% thermal efficiency in 1950 vs. 36.2% in 1975), in <b6_0><b9_0>1950<b9_0/><b6_0/> diesel traction was about twice as energy efficient as electric traction (in terms of net tonne-km of freight per kg of fuel). But as efficiency of electricity generation (and thus of electric traction) improved, by about <a1_0>1965<a1_0/> electric railways became more efficient than diesel. After the mid <b7_0>1970s<b7_0/> electrics used about <a2_0>25% less fuel per ton-km<a2_0/>. However diesels were mainly used on single track lines with a fair amount of traffic  so that the lower fuel consumption of electrics may be in part due to <a3_0>better operating conditions on electrified lines<a3_0/> (such as double tracking) rather than inherent energy efficiency. Nevertheless, the cost of diesel fuel was about <a4_0>1.5 times more (per unit of heat energy content<a4_0/>) than <b8_0>that of the fuel used in electric power plants<b8_0/> (that generated electricity), thus making electric railways even more energy-cost effective.
